hops.name: Sterling
hops.notes:
Flavor is a cross between Saaz and Mt Hood
Used for: Lagers, Ales, Pilsners
Aroma: Herbal, spicy, some floral and citrus hints
Substitutes: Saaz, Polish Lublin

hops.name: Sterling
hops.notes:
Flavor is a cross between Saaz and Mt Hood
Used for: Lagers, Ales, Pilsners
Aroma: Herbal, spicy, some floral and citrus hints
Substitutes: Saaz, Polish Lublin

hops.name: Sterling
hops.notes:
Flavor is a cross between Saaz and Mt Hood
Used for: Lagers, Ales, Pilsners
Aroma: Herbal, spicy, some floral and citrus hints
Substitutes: Saaz, Polish Lublin

hops.name: Mt. Hood
hops.notes:
Used for: European Lagers, finishing
Aroma: Mild with a clean aroma, neutral flavor. Somewhat pungent.
Substitutes: Hallertauer, Liberty, Crystal

hops.name: Willamette
hops.notes:
Used for: Finishing American and British Ales
Aroma: Mild, grassy, floral, slightly spicy
Substitutes: Fuggles, East Kent Goldings
Examples: Sierra Nevada Porter, Ballard Bitter

hops.name: Willamette
hops.notes:
Used for: Finishing American and British Ales
Aroma: Mild, grassy, floral, slightly spicy
Substitutes: Fuggles, East Kent Goldings
Examples: Sierra Nevada Porter, Ballard Bitter

fermentables.name: Pale Malt (2 Row) US
fermentables.notes: Base malt for all beer styles

fermentables.name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 20L
fermentables.notes:
Adds body, color and improves head retention.
Also called "Crystal" malt.

fermentables.name: Munich Malt
fermentables.notes:
Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a reddish amber color to the beer.
Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention.
Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

fermentables.name: Victory Malt
fermentables.notes:
Toasted malt that adds a "Biscuit" or toasted flavor to English ales.
Use for: Nut brown ales, porters

miscs.name: Gypsum (Calcium Sulfate)
miscs.notes: Reduces PH of water for mashing and sparging. Alters water profile -- used to harden soft water. Use the BeerSmith Water Profile tool to determine amount to add.

miscs.name: Baking Soda
miscs.notes: Baking Soda (NaHCO3) may be used as a water mineral to adjust brewing water for mashing.

miscs.name: Epsom Salt (MgSO4)
miscs.notes: Water agent used to modify water profile. Use the BeerSmith Water Profile tool to determine amount to add.

miscs.name: Chalk
miscs.notes: Chalk (CaCO3) can be used as a water addition to adjust mineral content for mashing.

miscs.name: Irish Moss
miscs.notes: Fining agent that aids in the post-boil protein break. Reduces protein chill haze and improves beer clarity.

yeasts.name: American Ale II
yeasts.notes: Clean, tart, nutty flavor. More fruity than Wyeast American Ale yeast.
yeasts.best_for: All American Ales, Brown Ales, Barley Wine

waters.name: Columbus, OH (HCWP) - Hoppy Bitter Profile
waters.notes: Additions to acheive this profile are added to Columbus Hap Cremean water profile

style.name: American IPA
style.notes: A decidedly hoppy and bitter, moderately strong American pale ale. An American version of the historical English style, brewed using American ingredients and attitude.
style.profile:
Aroma: A prominent to intense hop aroma with a citrusy, floral, perfume-like, resinous, piney, and/or fruity character derived from American hops. Many versions are dry hopped and can have an additional grassy aroma, although this is not required. Some clean malty sweetness may be found in the background, but should be at a lower level than in English examples. Fruitiness, either from esters or hops, may also be detected in some versions, although a neutral fermentation character is also acceptable. Some alcohol may be noted.
Appearance: Color ranges from medium gold to medium reddish copper; some versions can have an orange-ish tint. Should be clear, although unfiltered dry-hopped versions may be a bit hazy. Good head stand with white to off-white color should persist.
Flavor: Hop flavor is medium to high, and should reflect an American hop character with citrusy, floral, resinous, piney or fruity aspects. Medium-high to very high hop bitterness, although the malt backbone will support the strong hop character and provide the best balance. Malt flavor should be low to medium, and is generally clean and malty sweet although some caramel or toasty flavors are acceptable at low levels. No diacetyl. Low fruitiness is acceptable but not required. The bitterness may linger into the aftertaste but should not be harsh. Medium-dry to dry finish. Some clean alcohol flavor can be noted in stronger versions. Oak is inappropriate in this style. May be slightly sulfury, but most examples do not exhibit this character.
Mouthfeel: Smooth, medium-light to medium-bodied mouthfeel without hop-derived astringency, although moderate to medium-high carbonation can combine to render an overall dry sensation in the presence of malt sweetness. Some smooth alcohol warming can and should be sensed in stronger (but not all) versions. Body is generally less than in English counterparts.
style.ingredients: Pale ale malt (well-modified and suitable for single-temperature infusion mashing); American hops; American yeast that can give a clean or slightly fruity profile. Generally all-malt, but mashed at lower temperatures for high attenuation. Water character varies from soft to moderately sulfate. Versions with a noticeable Rye character (“RyePA”) should be entered in the Specialty category.
style.examples: Bell’s Two-Hearted Ale, AleSmith IPA, Russian River Blind Pig IPA, Stone IPA, Three Floyds Alpha King, Great Divide Titan IPA, Bear Republic Racer 5 IPA, Victory Hop Devil, Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale, Anderson Valley Hop Ottin’, Dogfish Head 60 Minute IPA, Founder’s Centennial IPA, Anchor Liberty Ale, Harpoon IPA, Avery IPA

equipment.name: RIMS Setup
equipment.notes: Boil off is unknown for this setup right now. Electric in the boil will help improve this.

mash.name: Temperature Mash, 1 Step, Medium Body
mash.notes: Temperature mash for use when mashing in a brew pot over a heat source such as the stove. Use heat to maintain desired temperature during the mash.

mash_steps.name: Saccharification
mash_steps.description: Add 19.31 qt of water at 159.0 F

steps.title: Strike Water
steps.content: Add the following ingredients to the Hot Liquor Tank:

todos.step: 10.25 gal water
13.18 g Gypsum (Calcium Sulfate)
0.78 g Baking Soda
0.23 g Epsom Salt (MgSO4)
0.20 g Chalk

objects.name: Columbus, OH (HCWP) - Hoppy Bitter Profile
objects.notes: Additions to acheive this profile are added to Columbus Hap Cremean water profile

objects.name: Gypsum (Calcium Sulfate)
objects.notes: Reduces PH of water for mashing and sparging. Alters water profile -- used to harden soft water. Use the BeerSmith Water Profile tool to determine amount to add.

objects.name: Baking Soda
objects.notes: Baking Soda (NaHCO3) may be used as a water mineral to adjust brewing water for mashing.

objects.name: Epsom Salt (MgSO4)
objects.notes: Water agent used to modify water profile. Use the BeerSmith Water Profile tool to determine amount to add.

objects.name: Chalk
objects.notes: Chalk (CaCO3) can be used as a water addition to adjust mineral content for mashing.

todos.step: Open HLT outlet
Open pump outlet
Close top Mash Tun inlet so water flows back to HLT
Close bypass valve from Mash Tun outlet

objects.name: Saccharification
objects.description: Add 19.31 qt of water at 159.0 F

steps.title: Fill Mash Tun
steps.content: Fill mash tun with 19.31 qt water

todos.step: Open top Mash Tun inlet so water flows into the Mash Tun
Add 19.31 qt water
Close HLT outlet
Open pump outlet
Cap top HLT inlet from RIMS tube
Open top Mash Tun inlet so water flows back to Mash Tun
Open Mash Tun outlet back to pump
Open HLT bypass valve so water flows back to Mash Tun

steps.title: Heat Strike Water in Mash Tun

objects.name: Saccharification
objects.description: Add 19.31 qt of water at 159.0 F

steps.title: Add Ingredients to Mash Tun
steps.content: Add the following ingredients to the Mash Tun:

todos.step: 9 lbs 8.0 oz Pale Malt (2 Row) US
2 lbs Caramel/Crystal Malt - 20L
8.0 oz Munich Malt
4.0 oz Victory Malt
13.18 g Gypsum (Calcium Sulfate)
0.78 g Baking Soda
0.23 g Epsom Salt (MgSO4)
0.20 g Chalk

objects.name: Pale Malt (2 Row) US
objects.notes: Base malt for all beer styles

objects.name: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 20L
objects.notes:
Adds body, color and improves head retention.
Also called "Crystal" malt.

objects.name: Munich Malt
objects.notes:
Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a reddish amber color to the beer.
Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention.
Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

objects.name: Victory Malt
objects.notes:
Toasted malt that adds a "Biscuit" or toasted flavor to English ales.
Use for: Nut brown ales, porters

objects.name: Gypsum (Calcium Sulfate)
objects.notes: Reduces PH of water for mashing and sparging. Alters water profile -- used to harden soft water. Use the BeerSmith Water Profile tool to determine amount to add.

objects.name: Baking Soda
objects.notes: Baking Soda (NaHCO3) may be used as a water mineral to adjust brewing water for mashing.

objects.name: Epsom Salt (MgSO4)
objects.notes: Water agent used to modify water profile. Use the BeerSmith Water Profile tool to determine amount to add.

objects.name: Chalk
objects.notes: Chalk (CaCO3) can be used as a water addition to adjust mineral content for mashing.

objects.name: Saccharification
objects.description: Add 19.31 qt of water at 159.0 F

steps.title: Saccharification Rest
steps.content: Holding Mash at 150.0 F for 1 hour 30 minutes

objects.name: Saccharification
objects.description: Add 19.31 qt of water at 159.0 F

steps.title: Mash Out Rest
steps.content: Holding Mash at 168.0 F for 10 minutes

todos.step: Close the Mash Tun outlet valve
Close the HLT bypass valve
Disconnect the bypass line from the bypass valve and route into the boil kettle from the Mash Tun outlet valve
Close boil kettle valve
Open HLT outlet
Open pump outlet
Close top Mash Tun inlet so water flows back to HLT
Remove HLT inlet cap and route back to HLT

objects.name: Temperature Mash, 1 Step, Medium Body
objects.notes: Temperature mash for use when mashing in a brew pot over a heat source such as the stove. Use heat to maintain desired temperature during the mash.

steps.title: Sparge
steps.content: Open the sparge valves and fill the boil kettle to 7.71 gal

todos.step: Boil kettle has been filled to 7.71 gal

steps.title: Prepare for Boil
steps.content: Disconnect Mash Setup and  Connect Chiller:

todos.step: Close HLT outlet valve.
Ensure Mash Tun outlet valve is closed.
Disconnect pump inlet into a small bucket allowing liquid to empty from pump and tubing completely.
Disconnect connection from pump outlet to RIMS inlet after liquid has drained.
Connect from pump outlet to wort chiller inlet.
Connect from pump inlet to boil kettle ball valve.
Connect from wort chiller outlet to whirlpool bulkhead.

steps.title: Bring to Boil
steps.content: Bringing the Boil Kettle up to a rolling boil.

todos.step: Connect garden hoses to the wort chiller inlet and outlet.
Connect the chiller inlet garden hose to the garden spigot.
Confirm when the boil kettle begins to boil.

steps.title: Prepare for Wort Chilling
steps.content: Put valves in reciculating position and raise boil kettle:

todos.step: Open boil kettle outlet valve.
Ensure whirlpool bulkhead is in the 'recirculation' position.
Run tubing from whirlpool bulkhead 'carboy fill' outlet to carboy.
Raise boil kettle high enough to prime the pump.
Confirm when outlet of counterflow chiller has reached 68 °F.
Open whirlpool bulkhead to direct the flow of wort into the fermentation vessel.
Confirm when 5.00 gal has been added to the fermenter.

activeStep.title: Strike Water
activeStep.content: Add the following ingredients to the Hot Liquor Tank:

todos.step: 10.25 gal water
13.18 g Gypsum (Calcium Sulfate)
0.78 g Baking Soda
0.23 g Epsom Salt (MgSO4)
0.20 g Chalk
